When a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it came (e.g., if they cross a mountain range or a river or if they settle on a new island so that they cannot easily return), they often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor, as opposed to what they needed before.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adaptations as before.
As time passes, the new population begins to adapt to its new environment, and then it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years two populations look so different that they can no longer be assigned to the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the emergence of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from the technological push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by a fundamental logic that is linked to scientific laws and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general views. One, that the development of technology follows a path that is largely outside of cultural or political influence, and two, that technology itself has effects on societies that are more inherent than socially determined.
One could argue that the automobile is unavoidably linked to the development of roads.
However, a nationwide road network for only a small number of cars is not economically viable. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.

The widespread ownership of automobiles also leads to a higher number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new technologies in the medical field to repair damaged bodies.

Japanese work culture is hierarchical and formal, perhaps more so than what Westerners are used to.
